comment_text.mn81:1.1: This lively story is one of the most developed of the early canonical Jātakas. The popularity of the story is attested by the many parallels, which include a retelling of the story by the deity who had been Ghaṭīkāra (SN 1.50). Ghaṭīkāra’s virtues as an ideal lay follower are extolled; his kindness, faith, and contentment, and especially his practice of economic harmlessness through rejection of the contractual market economy.
comment_text.mn81:3.1: Each of the occasions when the Buddha smiled in this way served as an introduction to an uplifting story of the past. In MN 83, the Buddha tells of the fabled king Maghadeva of Mithilā, who went forth and practice the divine meditations. AN 5.180, like the current sutta, tells the story of a virtuous layperson in the time of Kassapa Buddha. Both the Kassapa stories are set in Kosala. | Vebhaliṅga is known only from this context and there are many variant readings. | Here the compound gāmanigama, elsewhere “village or town” clearly means “market town”. The same idiom is found in Sanskrit versions of this text (vaibhiḍiṅgī nāma grāmanigamo, Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya 17.390).
comment_text.mn81:6.2: Various texts of the northern Sarvāstivāda movement, including the Madhyama-āgama and the Saṅghabhedavastu, speak instead of the potter Nandīpāla and the Brahmin youth Uttara. | Ghaṭīkāra (“potter”) Nandīpāla is also referred to by his clan name Bhaggava. | Jotipāla means “guardian of the sacred flame”, i.e. someone who maintains the Vedic fire ritual, as attested by another Jotipāla of the past (DN 19:47.26). Yet another Jotipāla was a religious founder of the past (AN 6.54:18.1, AN 7.73:2.5). The name seems to appear only in Buddhist sources. Given that it is always in legendary contexts, it is probably a vocational epithet like Ghaṭīkāra.
comment_text.mn81:6.4: Kassapa (Sanskrit Kaśyapa) means “tortoise”. It is a common Brahmanical clan name, stemming from an ancient figure reckoned as the eldest of the “seven sages”, to whom some Vedic verses are attributed. Further details of the Buddha Kassapa’s time are found at DN 14:1.4.6, SN 15.20:4.1, and SN 48.57:3.1.
comment_text.mn81:6.5: Sādhusammata is normally an epithet of (real or supposed) saints. Here it is the “sight” (dassana) of the saint that is deemed holy. This is an early example of the belief known in Hinduism as darshana, that the sight of a holy person, place, or object was auspicious and conveyed blessings on the seer. This topic is also treated at Snp 4.4 and AN 6.30.
comment_text.mn81:6.16: Sotti is uncertain. I take it as from the root suc in the sense “cleanser”. However, it may be related to Sanskrit śukti (from the same root), which is mentioned by Varāhamihira as an ingredient in perfumed bath powders fit for a king (Bṛhat Saṁhitā 77). There, it is probably either powdered or ashen oyster shell, which is included as an exfoliant in some modern soaps, or else perfume from a plant whose leaves or flowers resemble oysters. The commentary, identifying it with the kuruvindakasutti that was banned for mendicants at Kd 15:1.3.18, evidently derives it from sutta (“string”) and explains it as a string of resin-balls compounded with kuruvindaka (itself uncertain, possibly a herb). However, these explanations all seem dubious, as Pali texts treat sotti as a normal means of washing, and should not require specialized ingredients or methods (AN 3.70:8.2, MN 93:10.5).
comment_text.mn81:8.1: The ovaṭṭikā is the turned-over hem of a skirt or sarong that holds it up (see Bu NP 10:1.2.7).
comment_text.mn81:8.5: Leaving him, apparently, naked standing in the water.
comment_text.mn81:9.1: Manusmṛti 4.83 forbids grabbing hair (keśagraha), which was an act of dominance in wrestling. It is forbidden in anger, notes Medhātithi’s commentary, but permitted in sex. Mahābhārata 5.91.11a beautifully explains how such rules are meant to be understood in context: “The learned regard him to be a wretch who does not by his solicitation seek to save a friend who is about to sink in calamity. Striving to the best of his might, even to the extent of seizing him by the hair, one should seek to dissuade a friend from an improper act. In that case, he that acts so, instead of incurring blame, reaps praise” (Kisari Mohan Ganguli’s translation, Section 93, Bhagavat-yāna Parva).
comment_text.mn81:9.7: Pottery is said to be a low craft at Bu Pc 2:2.1.30.
comment_text.mn81:9.10: Dohī is “milking”, as in anavasesadohī “milk dry”, an idiom which is used in the sense of “pushing things too far” (MN 33:13.1, AN 11.17:12.1).
comment_text.mn81:13.1: Varanasi, one of the oldest cities in the world, was the capital of the Kāsī kingdom. It lost its status as an independent kingdom shortly before the Buddha, when it was taken over by Kosala. It appears in countless Buddhist stories of the past as the dominant city of the region in what appears to be a timeless and ageless past. However, despite its great antiquity, it is a historical settlement, of which the discovered remains date back to perhaps 1200 BCE; it was a capital city from perhaps 800 BCE. It would have enjoyed its status as a major city for a period of a few hundred years before the Buddha, during which time all these stories were set.
comment_text.mn81:14.1: Kikī (“blue jay”) is also the king in the time of Kassapa at DN 14:1.12.20. No king of this name appears to be attested in Puranic lineages. By the time of the Buddha, the much-conquered city of Varanasi was subject to first Kosala and then Magadha. This sutta establishes, however, that the true ancient king of the city was in fact a disciple of the past Buddha. | The suttas of this chapter all deal with kings in one way or another. Leaving aside the final five, all of which which Pasenadi of Kosala, we encounter royalty of of Kuru, Kāsī, Videha, Sūrasena, Bhaggā, and indirectly of Avanti and Kosambī. Thus the chapter serves to show that not just the well-known cases of Pasenadi and Bimbisāra, as well as the republican nations such as Vajjī and Sakya, were devoted to the Buddha, but the overwhelming majority of the kings of the time. Many, perhaps all, of these kings belong to what the Puranas later called the “lunar” dynasty, in contrast with the Buddha’s “solar” lineage.
comment_text.mn81:16.1: For “soft saffron rice” prefer the reading paṇḍumudikassa.
comment_text.mn81:17.6: The king is promising that the offerings for the whole Sangha will be as luxurious as the ones just offered.
comment_text.mn81:17.17: The Buddha does not take the bait of describing someone  as “better”; rather, he describes Ghaṭīkāra’s qualities.
comment_text.mn81:18.9: This shows him to be one of the noble ones.
comment_text.mn81:18.10: This is equivalent to the eight precepts.
comment_text.mn81:18.11: The same is said of Buddhist mendicants at SN 42.10:2.4. This parallels the ten precepts of the sāmaṇera, which forbid using money (Kd 1:56.1.14).
comment_text.mn81:18.12: Also said of ancient Brahmanical hermits at DN 27:22.6. Digging the earth is an offence for mendicants (Bu Pc 10).
comment_text.mn81:18.14: He made a living by purely voluntary exchange rather than contractual obligations.
comment_text.mn81:19.3: The Buddha uses Ghaṭīkāra’s clan name, as he does at SN 1.50:11.2.
comment_text.mn81:19.5: This appears to technically violate Bu Pc 40, which requires that food be given with the hands, not simply by speech. However, not all Buddhas lay down the exact same Vinaya rules. Several parallels explain this by saying that Kassapa was following the customs of the mystical land of Uttarakuru (MA 63 at T i 502a19; T i 502b8; Saṅghabhedavastu 17:391 at Gnoli 1978a:27,14 and D (1) ’dul ba, ga 8a3), where no-one had any possessions (DN 32:7.4).
comment_text.mn81:21.6: Āvesana is found here and at MN 140:2.1 of a potter’s workshop, at Kd 15:11.5.15 of a sewing hut, and is mentioned at Manu 9.264 as an “artisan’s workshop” (kārukāveśana).
comment_text.mn81:22.1: “Suitable sauce” (tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṁ) is also at DN 17:2.15.10 and SN 22.96:4.10, where it describes a similarly luxurious meal. | A secondary theme of this parable is to highlight the different attitudes to offering. Kikī is generous, but his offering is extravagant and indulgent, and ultimately serves his desires, whereas Ghaṭīkāra is concerned only to help with what is needed at the time.
comment_text.mn81:22.6: The two words alaṁ me encapsulate the radical basis of a Buddhist economy.
comment_text.mn81:23.2: This phrase marks canonical Jātaka stories at DN 17:2.14.2, MN 83:21.2, AN 3.15:5.2, and AN 9.20:5.2.

root_text.mn81:6.3: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn81:6.4: ‘āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.

root_text.mn81:9.7: Yatra hi nāmāyaṁ ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro ittarajacco samāno amhākaṁ sīsaṁnhātānaṁ kesesu parāmasitabbaṁ maññissati;

Jotipālo pana māṇavo kassapena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena saddhiṁ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn81:10.2: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:10.3: ‘ayaṁ me, bhante, jotipālo māṇavo sahāyo piyasahāyo.
root_text.mn81:10.5: Atha kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho ghaṭikārañca kumbhakāraṁ jotipālañca māṇavaṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṁsesi.
root_text.mn81:10.6: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro ca kumbhakāro jotipālo ca māṇavo kassapena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṁsitā kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkamiṁsu.
root_text.mn81:11.1: Atha kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikāraṁ kumbhakāraṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:11.2: ‘imaṁ nu tvaṁ, samma ghaṭikāra, dhammaṁ suṇanto atha ca pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ na pabbajissasī’ti?

root_text.mn81:11.4: ‘Tena hi, samma ghaṭikāra, ahaṁ agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmī’ti.
root_text.mn81:12.1: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro ca kumbhakāro jotipālo ca māṇavo yena kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. root_text.mn81:14.3: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.

root_text.mn81:14.5: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṁsito kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ etadavoca:

root_text.mn81:14.7: Adhivāsesi kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho tuṇhībhāvena.
root_text.mn81:15.1: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapassa bhagavato sammāsambuddhassa adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn81:16.1: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā paṇḍupuṭakassa sālino vigatakāḷakaṁ anekasūpaṁ anekabyañjanaṁ, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa kālaṁ ārocāpesi:
root_text.mn81:17.1: Atha kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kikissa kāsirañño nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena.
root_text.mn81:17.2: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
root_text.mn81:17.3: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ bhuttāviṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn81:17.4: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:17.10: tatiyampi kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:17.15: Atha kho, ānanda, kikissa kāsirañño ‘na me kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho adhivāseti bārāṇasiyaṁ vassāvāsan’ti ahudeva aññathattaṁ, ahu domanassaṁ.
root_text.mn81:17.16: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:17.17: ‘atthi nu kho, bhante, añño koci mayā upaṭṭhākataro’ti?
root_text.mn81:18.4: Tuyhaṁ kho pana, mahārāja, na me kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho adhivāseti bārāṇasiyaṁ vassāvāsanti attheva aññathattaṁ, atthi domanassaṁ.
root_text.mn81:18.5: Tayidaṁ ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa natthi ca na ca bhavissati.
root_text.mn81:18.6: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro buddhaṁ saraṇaṁ gato, dhammaṁ saraṇaṁ gato, saṅghaṁ saraṇaṁ gato.
root_text.mn81:18.7: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, adinnādānā paṭivirato, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato, musāvādā paṭivirato, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato.
root_text.mn81:18.8: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato, dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgato, saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgato, ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato.
root_text.mn81:18.9: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro dukkhe nikkaṅkho, dukkhasamudaye nikkaṅkho, dukkhanirodhe nikkaṅkho, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya nikkaṅkho.
root_text.mn81:18.10: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro ekabhattiko brahmacārī sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo.
root_text.mn81:18.11: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro nikkhittamaṇisuvaṇṇo apetajātarūparajato.
root_text.mn81:18.12: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro pannamusalo na sahatthā pathaviṁ khaṇati.
root_text.mn81:18.13: Yaṁ hoti kūlapaluggaṁ vā mūsikukkaro vā taṁ kājena āharitvā bhājanaṁ karitvā evamāha:
root_text.mn81:18.14: “ettha yo icchati taṇḍulapaṭibhastāni vā muggapaṭibhastāni vā kaḷāyapaṭibhastāni vā nikkhipitvā yaṁ icchati taṁ haratū”ti.
root_text.mn81:18.15: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro andhe jiṇṇe mātāpitaro poseti.
root_text.mn81:18.16: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
root_text.mn81:19.1: Ekamidāhaṁ, mahārāja, samayaṁ vegaḷiṅge nāma gāmanigame viharāmi.
root_text.mn81:19.2: Atha khvāhaṁ, mahārāja, pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn81:19.3: “handa ko nu kho ayaṁ bhaggavo gato”ti?
root_text.mn81:19.4: “Nikkhanto kho te, bhante, upaṭṭhāko antokumbhiyā odanaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjā”ti.
root_text.mn81:19.5: Atha khvāhaṁ, mahārāja, kumbhiyā odanaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
root_text.mn81:19.6: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:19.7: “ko kumbhiyā odanaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
root_text.mn81:19.8: “Kassapo, tāta, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho kumbhiyā odanaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
root_text.mn81:19.9: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa etadahosi:
root_text.mn81:19.11: yassa me kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho evaṁ abhivissattho”ti.
root_text.mn81:19.12: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāraṁ kumbhakāraṁ aḍḍhamāsaṁ pītisukhaṁ na vijahati, sattāhaṁ mātāpitūnaṁ.
root_text.mn81:20.1: Ekamidāhaṁ, mahārāja, samayaṁ tattheva vegaḷiṅge nāma gāmanigame viharāmi.
root_text.mn81:20.2: Atha khvāhaṁ, mahārāja, pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn81:20.3: “handa ko nu kho ayaṁ bhaggavo gato”ti?
root_text.mn81:20.4: “Nikkhanto kho te, bhante, upaṭṭhāko anto kaḷopiyā kummāsaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjā”ti.
root_text.mn81:20.5: Atha khvāhaṁ, mahārāja, kaḷopiyā kummāsaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
root_text.mn81:20.6: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:20.7: “ko kaḷopiyā kummāsaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
root_text.mn81:20.8: “Kassapo, tāta, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho kaḷopiyā kummāsaṁ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṁ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti.
root_text.mn81:20.9: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa etadahosi:
root_text.mn81:20.11: yassa me kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho evaṁ abhivissattho”ti.
root_text.mn81:20.12: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāraṁ kumbhakāraṁ aḍḍhamāsaṁ pītisukhaṁ na vijahati, sattāhaṁ mātāpitūnaṁ.
root_text.mn81:21.1: Ekamidāhaṁ, mahārāja, samayaṁ tattheva vegaḷiṅge nāma gāmanigame viharāmi.
root_text.mn81:21.2: Tena kho pana samayena kuṭi ovassati.
root_text.mn81:21.4: “gacchatha, bhikkhave, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa nivesane tiṇaṁ jānāthā”ti.
root_text.mn81:21.5: Evaṁ vutte, mahārāja, te bhikkhū maṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn81:21.6: “natthi kho, bhante, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa nivesane tiṇaṁ, atthi ca khvāssa āvesane tiṇacchadanan”ti.
root_text.mn81:21.7: “Gacchatha, bhikkhave, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa āvesanaṁ uttiṇaṁ karothā”ti.
root_text.mn81:21.8: Atha kho te, mahārāja, bhikkhū ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa āvesanaṁ uttiṇamakaṁsu.
root_text.mn81:21.9: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro te bhikkhū etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn81:21.11: “Bhikkhū, bhagini, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa kuṭi ovassatī”ti.
root_text.mn81:21.13: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
root_text.mn81:21.15: “Bhikkhū, tāta, kassapassa kira bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa kuṭi ovassatī”ti.
root_text.mn81:21.16: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa etadahosi:
root_text.mn81:21.18: yassa me kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho evaṁ abhivissattho”ti.
root_text.mn81:21.19: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāraṁ kumbhakāraṁ aḍḍhamāsaṁ pītisukhaṁ na vijahati, sattāhaṁ mātāpitūnaṁ.
root_text.mn81:21.20: Atha kho, mahārāja, āvesanaṁ sabbantaṁ temāsaṁ ākāsacchadanaṁ aṭṭhāsi, na devotivassi.
root_text.mn81:21.22: ‘Lābhā, bhante, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa, suladdhā, bhante, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa
root_text.mn81:22.1: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa pañcamattāni taṇḍulavāhasatāni pāhesi paṇḍupuṭakassa sālino tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṁ.
root_text.mn81:22.2: Atha kho te, ānanda, rājapurisā ghaṭikāraṁ kumbhakāraṁ upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn81:22.3: ‘imāni kho, bhante, pañcamattāni taṇḍulavāhasatāni kikinā kāsirājena pahitāni paṇḍupuṭakassa sālino tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṁ.
root_text.mn81:23.1: Siyā kho pana te, ānanda, evamassa:
root_text.mn81:23.2: ‘añño nūna tena samayena jotipālo māṇavo ahosī’ti.
root_text.mn81:23.3: Na kho panetaṁ, ānanda, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn81:23.4: Ahaṁ tena samayena jotipālo māṇavo ahosin”ti.
root_text.mn81:23.6: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn81:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn81:2.1: Then the Buddha left the road, and at a certain spot he smiled.
translation_text.mn81:2.3: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
translation_text.mn81:2.4: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”
translation_text.mn81:2.5: So Ānanda arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
translation_text.mn81:2.6: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
translation_text.mn81:2.7: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”
translation_text.mn81:3.1: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, there was a market town in this spot named Vebhaliṅga. It was successful and prosperous, populous, full of humans.
translation_text.mn81:3.2: And Kassapa, a blessed one, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, lived supported by Vebhaliṅga.
translation_text.mn81:3.3: It was here, in fact, that he had his monastery,
translation_text.mn81:3.4: where he advised the mendicant Saṅgha while seated.”
translation_text.mn81:4.1: Then Ānanda spread out his outer robe folded in four and said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn81:4.2: “Well then, sir, may the Blessed One sit here!
translation_text.mn81:4.3: Then this piece of land will have been occupied by two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas.”
translation_text.mn81:4.4: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.mn81:4.5: When he was seated he said to Venerable Ānanda:
translation_text.mn81:5.1: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, there was a market town in this spot named Vebhaliṅga. It was successful and prosperous, populous, full of humans.
translation_text.mn81:5.2: And Kassapa, a blessed one, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, lived supported by Vebhaliṅga.
translation_text.mn81:5.3: It was here, in fact, that he had his monastery,
translation_text.mn81:5.4: where he advised the mendicant Saṅgha while seated.
translation_text.mn81:6.1: The Buddha Kassapa had as chief supporter in Vebhaliṅga a potter named Ghaṭīkāra.
translation_text.mn81:6.2: Ghaṭīkāra had a dear friend named Jotipāla, a student.
translation_text.mn81:6.4: ‘Come, dear Jotipāla, let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn81:6.5: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:6.6: When he said this, Jotipāla said to him,
translation_text.mn81:6.8: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’
translation_text.mn81:6.10: and a third time, Ghaṭīkāra addressed Jotipāla,
translation_text.mn81:6.11: ‘Come, dear Jotipāla, let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn81:6.12: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:6.13: For a third time, Jotipāla said to him,
translation_text.mn81:6.15: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’
translation_text.mn81:6.16: ‘Well then, dear Jotipāla, let’s take some bathing cleanser and go to the river to bathe.’
translation_text.mn81:7.2: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.
translation_text.mn81:7.3: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn81:7.4: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:7.5: When he said this, Jotipāla said to him,
translation_text.mn81:7.7: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’
translation_text.mn81:7.9: and a third time, Ghaṭīkāra addressed Jotipāla,
translation_text.mn81:7.10: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.
translation_text.mn81:7.11: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn81:7.12: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:7.13: For a third time, Jotipāla said to him,
translation_text.mn81:7.15: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’
translation_text.mn81:8.1: Then Ghaṭīkāra grabbed Jotipāla by the skirt-hem and said,
translation_text.mn81:8.2: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.
translation_text.mn81:8.3: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn81:8.4: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:8.5: So Jotipāla undid his skirt-hem and said to Ghaṭīkāra,
translation_text.mn81:8.7: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’
translation_text.mn81:9.1: Then Ghaṭīkāra grabbed Jotipāla by the hair of his freshly-washed head and said,
translation_text.mn81:9.2: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.
translation_text.mn81:9.3: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn81:9.4: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:9.7: how this potter Ghaṭīkāra, though of lowly birth, should presume to grab me by the hair of my freshly-washed head!
translation_text.mn81:9.8: This must be no ordinary matter.’
translation_text.mn81:9.10: ‘You’d even milk it to this extent, dear Ghaṭīkāra?’
translation_text.mn81:9.11: ‘I even milk it to this extent, dear Jotipāla.
translation_text.mn81:9.12: For that is how holy I deem it to see that Blessed One.’
translation_text.mn81:9.13: ‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, release me, we shall go.’
translation_text.mn81:10.1: Then Ghaṭīkāra the potter and Jotipāla the student went to the Buddha Kassapa. Ghaṭīkāra bowed and sat down to one side, but Jotipāla exchanged greetings with the Buddha and sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn81:10.2: Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa,
translation_text.mn81:10.3: ‘Sir, this is the student Jotipāla, my dear friend.
translation_text.mn81:10.5: Then the Buddha Kassapa educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.mn81:10.6: Then they got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha Kassapa, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn81:11.2: ‘Dear Ghaṭīkāra, you have heard this teaching, so why don’t you go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn81:11.3: ‘Don’t you know, dear Jotipāla, that I  provide for my blind old parents?’
translation_text.mn81:11.4: ‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
translation_text.mn81:12.1: Then Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla went to the Buddha Kassapa, bowed and sat down to one side. Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa,
translation_text.mn81:12.2: ‘Sir, this is the student Jotipāla, my dear friend.
translation_text.mn81:12.3: Please give him the going forth.’
translation_text.mn81:12.4: And Jotipāla the student received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.mn81:13.1: Not long after Jotipāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha Kassapa—having stayed in Vebhaliṅga as long as he pleased—set out for Varanasi.
translation_text.mn81:13.2: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Varanasi,
translation_text.mn81:13.3: where he stayed near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
translation_text.mn81:14.1: King Kikī of Kāsi heard that he had arrived.
translation_text.mn81:14.2: He had the finest carriages harnessed. He then mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Varanasi to see the Buddha Kassapa.
translation_text.mn81:14.3: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha Kassapa on foot. He bowed and sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn81:14.4: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.mn81:14.5: Then King Kikī said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn81:14.6: ‘Sir, would the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?’
translation_text.mn81:14.7: The Buddha Kassapa consented with silence.
translation_text.mn81:15.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, King Kikī got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn81:16.1: And when the night had passed, King Kikī had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home—soft saffron rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
translation_text.mn81:16.2: ‘Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.’
translation_text.mn81:17.1: Then Kassapa Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of King Kikī, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn81:17.2: Then King Kikī served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.mn81:17.3: When the Buddha Kassapa had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, King Kikī took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.mn81:17.4: There he said to the Buddha Kassapa,
translation_text.mn81:17.5: ‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Varanasi for the rainy season.
translation_text.mn81:17.6: The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’
translation_text.mn81:17.8: I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’
translation_text.mn81:17.10: and a third time King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa,
translation_text.mn81:17.11: ‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Varanasi for the rainy season.
translation_text.mn81:17.12: The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’
translation_text.mn81:17.14: I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’
translation_text.mn81:17.15: Then King Kikī, thinking, ‘The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Varanasi,’ became sad and upset.
translation_text.mn81:17.16: Then King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa,
translation_text.mn81:17.17: ‘Sir, do you have another supporter better than me?’
translation_text.mn81:18.1: ‘Great king, there is a market town named Vebhaliṅga,
translation_text.mn81:18.2: where there is a potter named Ghaṭīkāra.
translation_text.mn81:18.4: Now, great king, when you thought, “The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Varanasi,” you became sad and upset.
translation_text.mn81:18.5: But Ghaṭīkāra doesn’t get upset, nor will he.
translation_text.mn81:18.6: Ghaṭīkāra has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn81:18.7: He doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.
translation_text.mn81:18.8: He has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and possesses the ethics loved by the noble ones.
translation_text.mn81:18.9: He is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
translation_text.mn81:18.10: He eats in one part of the day; he’s chaste, ethical, and of good character.
translation_text.mn81:18.11: He has set aside gems and gold, and quit using gold and currency.
translation_text.mn81:18.12: He has put down the shovel and doesn’t dig the earth with his own hands.
translation_text.mn81:18.13: He takes what has crumbled off by a riverbank or been dug up by mice, and brings it back in a carrier. When he has made a pot, he says,
translation_text.mn81:18.14: “Anyone may leave bagged sesame, mung beans, or chickpeas here and take what they wish.”
translation_text.mn81:18.15: He provided for his blind old parents.
translation_text.mn81:18.16: And since he has ended the five lower fetters, Ghaṭīkāra will be reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.mn81:19.1: This one time, great king, I was staying near the market town of Vebhaliṅga.
translation_text.mn81:19.2: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them,
translation_text.mn81:19.4: “Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take rice from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.”
translation_text.mn81:19.5: So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.mn81:19.6: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,
translation_text.mn81:19.7: “Who took rice from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”
translation_text.mn81:19.8: “It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”
translation_text.mn81:19.11: in that the Buddha Kassapa trusts me so much!”
translation_text.mn81:19.12: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.
translation_text.mn81:20.1: Another time, great king, I was staying near that same market town of Vebhaliṅga.
translation_text.mn81:20.2: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them,
translation_text.mn81:20.4: “Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take porridge from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.”
translation_text.mn81:20.5: So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.
translation_text.mn81:20.6: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,
translation_text.mn81:20.7: “Who took porridge from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”
translation_text.mn81:20.8: “It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”
translation_text.mn81:20.11: to be trusted so much by the Buddha Kassapa!”
translation_text.mn81:20.12: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.
translation_text.mn81:21.1: Another time, great king, I was staying near that same market town of Vebhaliṅga.
translation_text.mn81:21.2: Now at that time my hut leaked.
translation_text.mn81:21.4: “Mendicants, go to Ghaṭīkāra’s home and find some grass.”
translation_text.mn81:21.5: When I said this, those mendicants said to me,
translation_text.mn81:21.6: “Sir, there’s no grass there, but his workshop has a grass roof.”
translation_text.mn81:21.7: “Then go to the workshop and strip the grass.”
translation_text.mn81:21.9: Then Ghaṭīkāra’s parents said to those mendicants,
translation_text.mn81:21.10: “Who’s stripping the grass from the workshop?”
translation_text.mn81:21.11: “It’s the mendicants, sister. The Buddha’s hut is leaking.”
translation_text.mn81:21.12: “Take it, sirs! Take it, dearest ones!”
translation_text.mn81:21.13: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,
translation_text.mn81:21.14: “Who stripped the grass from the workshop?”
translation_text.mn81:21.15: “It was the mendicants, dear. It seems the Buddha’s hut is leaking.”
translation_text.mn81:21.18: to be trusted so much by the Buddha Kassapa!”
translation_text.mn81:21.19: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.
translation_text.mn81:21.20: Then the workshop remained with the atmosphere for a roof for the whole three months, but the heavens did not rain on it.
translation_text.mn81:21.21: And that, great king, is what Ghaṭīkāra the potter is like.’
translation_text.mn81:21.22: ‘Ghaṭīkāra the potter is fortunate, very fortunate,
translation_text.mn81:21.23: to be so trusted by the Buddha Kassapa.’
translation_text.mn81:22.1: Then King Kikī sent around five hundred loads of rice, soft saffron rice, and suitable sauce to Ghaṭīkāra.
translation_text.mn81:22.2: Then one of the king’s men approached Ghaṭīkāra and said,
translation_text.mn81:22.3: ‘Sir, these five hundred loads of rice, soft saffron rice, and suitable sauce have been sent to you by King Kikī of Kāsi.
translation_text.mn81:22.5: ‘The king has many duties, and much to do.
translation_text.mn81:22.7: Let this be for the king himself.’
translation_text.mn81:23.2: ‘Surely the student Jotipāla must have been someone else at that time?’
translation_text.mn81:23.3: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.mn81:23.4: I myself was the student Jotipāla at that time.”
translation_text.mn81:23.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn81:23.6: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
